review_title: Good company with a good mission.
job_title: Information Systems Analyst in Little Rock, AR
pros:
Baptist is a good company who's getting better. Recently, they have overcome politics and have made bold moves (specifically technology advancements) that though costly at the front-end, have already and will continue to place Baptist in a position to provide better patient care.

Lower-level management treats you right and fights for you. That's is why I think they have a low turn-over rate.

The mission of Baptist Health is made very clear and presented in daily huddles where the department gathers and spurs each other on. I like taking part in the huddles and I believe it has really changed our culture for the better.
cons:
As mentioned above, politics have really been an issue, especially with upper management. This hinders advancement in technology and therefore, what I believe is a deficit in patient care.

The pay is not up to par with cost of living. After working there for nearly 10 years, my salary is not near as much as my peers who are in the same field.

They are not flexible when it comes to working from home, especially if you or one of you family members are ill. Much of what we do is on the computer. We can do it anywhere. Unfortunately, management frowns upon working remotely.

job_title: Admissions Representative Nlr in North Little Rock, AR
pros: Credit union and employee recognition
cons: There's so many cons, sexual harassment by maintenance and security personnel. Supervisors are absolutely useless in admissions department. Your required to lie to patients about double billing and facility charges. The turnover is horrible with staff, they hire people with little to no experience and it puts other staff on tight situations being forced to train young people who lack basic knowledge or even respect for others and those who are sick. Your forced to do everyone's job when others are sometimes nowhere to be found to handle their own jobs. There's always a schoolyard type of drama in the ER between admissions reps and nursing staff. Absolutely no teamwork and it's not required. Sex sex sex....everywhere and with everyone. The hook up job. Bullying tactics between employees. The drama alone will drive you away screaming crying everyday. The admissions occurrence policy needs to be reevaluated, as does the essential personnel policy in the event of bad weather, if you are unable to get into work during an ice storm you will receive 2 occurrence for1call in. Dr excuses for sickness and appointments do not count, FMLA is required and abused by employees just needing a day off.

job_title: New Grad RN in Little Rock, AR
pros: Great benefits for new grads and they offered raises at the end of your first year. They also provided tuition reimbursement which was a plus!
cons: Gossiping co-workers and supervisors. No team work. Always short staffed. New nurses placed with terrible preceptors! Nurses have a max load of patients 6-7 with 2-3 admissions throughout the night.  The RN resident contract is a bunch of crap. If you quit or get fired you have to pay them $5000 in full to.come back or they will put it in collections. They are racist as far as co-workers. They make a lot of racial.slurs and there is always someone trying to twist your words and get you fired. Too.many lazy nurses, rude cna's and lazy secretary! Stay away!!!#

job_title: Registered Nurse in North Little Rock, AR
pros: Baptist Healthcare in North Little Rock Arkansas is a great place to work.  I was contracted through Centra Healthcare as a registered nurse and it was a pleasant experience.  We had block scheduling therefore I could plan ahead for days off.  The work load was pretty typical, most staff was helpful, equipment was up to date.
cons: I worked in the pool so I never knew what floor I would be working on.  Some were defiantly better than others.  I wouldn't work in the pool again.  If I'm offered another contract there I will hope for permanent placement on 1A.  The nurses there are awesome!

review_title: My thoughts on the good and the bad
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros:
Nice benefits, some good co-workers, good location compared to some other hospitals, ability to transfer jobs/departments, helping patients that actually need to be here is satisfying. They do have employee appreciate events, dillards days, nurse appreciatation day ect, 

Overall though I am grateful to have a job in this economy.
cons:
spending too much time on indoctrination such as BEST and Huddles, not realistic with  some goals or expectations  IE: " Don't be on a cell phone in the parking lot.", I have never seen as much politics or drama in a workplace. 

Nepotism is very common same as anywhere I suppose.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Little Rock, AR
pros: Position offers reasonable benefits and there is good schedule flexibility. Many PCTs are in nursing school or in a pre-professional education program and staff generally responds positively to provide observational opportunities when appropriate
cons: Consistent staffing issues. There is a central staffing service to help manage floors with their staffing needs, but due to self made schedules and a lack of interest in PCTs choosing to commit to certain floors (due to difficulty, reputation of staff, etc),  there is constant staffing shortages.  Even floors that have adequate permanent  staff suffer because members are pulled to work on other floors when central staffing cannot cover all needs.

job_title: CNA in Little Rock, AR
pros: benefits are pretty good. plenty of incentives. sometimes you are able to work extra hours when it is available. The paid time off is excellent compared to other companies. You won't get as many hours of paid time off if you work somewhere else. Or at least the places I have worked at.
cons: I would have liked for the raises to be better. You have to pretty much move around the company to get a decent raise. Sometimes you feel like you are overworked and not getting any praise for it.

job_title: Staff RN in Little Rock, AR
pros:
Love the people i have and still do work with.  They have good employees,  very sweet and deticated
to the patients and families.
cons: Upper management needs to be replaced with managers who care that they have such wonderful people working for them.  If Baptist had better upper management it would be an awsome place to work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: I love to help people and see what the power of prayer in a hospital will do! REALLY great benefits.  The VPs in administration make their way throughout the hospital and keep everyone straight, which is super important in a hospital. High level of security.
cons: Pay isn't as high as a couple of other hospitals. There has been quite a bit of construction going on as of late. Elevators in parking deck go out for a few hours like once a year.

job_title: Clinic Manager in Little Rock, AR
pros: I was given an orientation to learn my job.
cons: I was in orientation and had been there about six weeks when I went for a checkup and learned I had to go into the hospital for a lung biopsy.  The supervisor was annoyed  and irritated. They terminated me for missing days during probation without any compassion and no one came to see me in the hospital and I was in Baptist Hospital.  I had sarcoidosis and was on oxygen, very sick.  I felt like I was treated with no dignity or respect. Thankfully unemployment ruled in my favor.

job_title: Account Representative in Little Rock, AR
pros:
Prayer in the workplace
PTO
office luncheons
If you get a great sense of accomplishment from completing work, don't work here!! It never ends and it will be there when you get back to work the next day. The more you work the more work there is still left to do!
cons:
Cliques and more cliques...
Snakes in the Grass. When they want to get rid of you it is only a matter of time. Don't ask too many questions even when they tell you to Ask Questions. It's a setup

review_title: Excellent company to work for based on experience as a front-line employee , middle manager, and director
job_title: Program Director in Little Rock, AR
pros: Senior leadership, throughout the history of Baptist Health and today, is constantly looking forward.  Every decision is made with the future of the organization and its human capital in mind.  Leadership attempts to be as transparent as possible by sharing information and the rationale for decisions with employees at all levels of the organization whenever possible.  Daily "huddles" provide every employee consistent information about current institutional events and a forum to share information among their team members. The people and culture of the organization definitely set it apart from others.  Over the past 20 plus years I have seen the culture become somewhat less rigid and believe this is an improvement.  However, in an organization this large a somewhat rigid culture is necessary; we are dealing with the lives of others.  Overall the people who work here do the right thing and are there for one another when needed; we care about each other's success, take a great deal of pride in our individual work,  that of our team, and beyond.  Finally, Baptist Health is committed to education as evident by their financial support of Baptist Health Schools Little Rock, the employee tuition assistance program, and the support  of continuing education and career paths in place to assist employees in their personal growth.
cons: The organization is very large which can make it difficult to get some things accomplished in a timely manner.

review_title: Was a good place to work 15+ years ago; not so much anymore.
job_title: Information Systems in Little Rock, AR
pros: Good place to learn valuable skills. Lots of good people to work with. You may not be compensated for your efforts appropriately but you can at least learn the skills.
cons: Management and leadership seek to minimize/delay development/career opportunities/salary raises. The "Good job you earned your 2% annual raise" are a slap in the face given the rate of inflation.

review_title: CNA/IA in the Surgical/Trauma Intensive Care Unit
job_title: CNA/IA in Little Rock, AR
pros: I worked in this position for three years while going through college.  Baptist Health was a professional environment to work in that provided detailed up-front training for employees as well as continued education throughout each year.  The people at Baptist were friendly and I enjoyed coming to work.
cons: The most frustrating aspect of working at Baptist was the annual review from supervisor's which determined pay raise.  The design of the process is good, to provide feedback through good performance metrics.  The problem was with the implementation of the process, in which the supervisor's predetermined a score they were going to give you so that you would not get the maximum raise.  The raise was a matter of 0.25 cents per hour versus 0.45 cents per hour.  The supervisor could not give any explicit reasons for marking certain aspects of the review low, and when questioned extensively about each mark replied that the budget will not allow the highest compensation, so she must predetermine the maximum score she could give. This was very frustrating, made me angry, and instantly affected morale and perception about the company.  From that point on, I did not care to go the extra step that I had been proud to take before, simply because they don't effective recognize and reward for hard work.

review_title: Could've been a great place to work, management is only worried abt keeping unit costs low so that they look competent.
job_title: Staff RN in North Little Rock, AR
pros: They have a decent food court, but not as good as SVI.
cons: unsafe pt:nurse ratio, managers dont care. Asked for more learning opportunities to better pt care, reprimanded for this!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Little Rock, AR
pros: Small clinic with a strong family atmosphere.  A majority of clinic patients have been established 10 to 20+ years.
cons: Poor management for the past 5 years.  Desperately needs someone with good leadership and communication skills as well as the knowledge and experience with credentialing, insurance & billing, to name a few.

review_title: I'd rather die than work there again, and no I'm not a disgruntled ex-employee.  I'm a human with a back bone.
job_title: Registered Nurse in Sherwood, AR
pros: Decent insurance, crappy to no bonus, a few good nurses.
cons: Management gives not 2 cents about their staff, upper level management will side with manager even when half the staff makes formal complaints over and over and over again.  They are the reason I'm getting out of nursing.  They make people want to go postal!!

job_title: Nurse Tech in Little Rock, AR
pros: RNs, MDs, and the rest of the hospital staff are very professional and dedicated to serving patients and families. Great work atmosphere and culture. Prayer with patients and coworkers is not only acceptable but encouraged. Employees here simply go above and beyond for patients and each other. It was a great organization to work for.
cons: Busy and demanding shifts but that is to be expected at a hospital. At end of the day it was always worth it.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Little Rock, AR
pros: Professional environment and most of the doctors were good to work with.  Never really had anyone give me a hard time about anything.  Pay is decent but on the lower side.  They opted for the better charting system compared to other local hospitals.
cons: Better benefits at other hospitals in the area.  Staffing was an issue at times.  Outdated equipment.

job_title: in Little Rock, AR
pros: Good benefits, friendly coworkers, excellent place to work if you're a nurse, large healthcare system, Good ER, plenty of work to be done.
cons: Poorly managed, slow to no opportunity for advancement, hire new grads over experienced professionals, no respect from superiors, don't expect anyone to go out of their way for you.

review_title: Wouldn’t recommend for a forever career

job_title: Manager in Little Rock, AR

cons: Salary evaluation and structure could be more competitive.  Continue to make employees a high priority and train managers to treat them as a valuable asset.  Sometimes it feels that employees are easily replaced.

review_title: Stable employment, multiple opportunities for advancement.
job_title: RN Case Manager in Little Rock, AR
pros: Variety of jobs available, don't feel stuck in one spot. This facility is like a community.  There are many opportunities for lateral moves and advancement.
cons: Staffing sometimes is low.  This is not unique to this facility, but occurs in many organizations.  If you are unhappy in a position it's easy to move.

job_title: COTA in Little Rock, AR
pros: Very stable. Good benefits. Not the best pay out there but the environment is good. There are some great people who work here.
cons: The pay is low for the area, but it is still enough to make it competitive. Progress is very slow sometimes due to bureaucratic procedures.

review_title: It was an exhilarating experience of which I regret having.
